qas.question: When could white women and black men be in a union?
Where did 80% of free people of color in NC come from?
Who made unions with African women during the colonial years?
What happened to mixed-race children from mothers who were enslaved?
What can eighty percent of enslaved people of color in North Carolina be traced to?
What percentage of free people of color in Virginia can be traced to families in North Carolina?
Who made unions with African men after the colonial years?

context: <a0_0>In the colonial years<a0_0/>, while conditions were more fluid, <b8_0>white women<b8_0/>, indentured servant or free, and <b4_0>African men<b4_0/>, servant, slave or free, made unions. Because the women were free, their mixed-race children were <b5_0>born free<b5_0/>; they and their descendants formed most of the families of free people of color during the colonial period in Virginia. The <a2_0>scholar<a2_0/> Paul Heinegg found that <b7_0>eighty<b7_0/> percent of the free people of color in North Carolina in censuses <a3_0>from 1790–1810<a3_0/> could be traced to families free in <a1_0><b6_0>Virginia in colonial years<b6_0/><a1_0/>.
